title: 2  Population and health geography
text:
2.1 Understanding Population Distribution

2.1.1 Global Population Distribution
Uneven Distribution:

90% of the world’s population lives in the Northern Hemisphere.
Most people live near coastlines, rivers, and fertile land.
Only ~30% of Earth’s land is habitable for dense populations.

Factors Influencing Population Distribution:

2.1.1.1 Physical Factors

Climate (e.g., dense populations in temperate regions).
Landforms (e.g., river valleys vs. deserts).
Natural resources (e.g., oil-rich regions).



2.1.1.2 Human Factors

Political stability and governance.
Economic opportunities (e.g., industrial hubs).
Cultural and historical reasons (e.g., religious sites).



2.1.1.3 Case Study: Population Density in Asia
China and India account for 35% of the world’s population due to:

Fertile lands (Ganges & Yangtze river valleys).
Monsoon climate supporting agriculture.
Historical urbanization and trade centers.

title: 2  Population and health geography
text:
2.2 Population Growth and Decline

2.2.1 Measuring Population Growth
Crude Birth Rate (CBR): Number of births per 1,000 people per year.
Crude Death Rate (CDR): Number of deaths per 1,000 people per year.
Natural Increase Rate (NIR):

Formula: NIR = CBR - CDR
If NIR > 0, population grows; if NIR < 0, population declines.


2.2.1.1 Demographic Transition Model (DTM)
A model explaining how populations change over time in response to economic and social progress.








Stage
Characteristics
Example Countries




1: Pre-Industrial
High birth & death rates, slow growth
Isolated tribes (Amazon, Congo)


2: Early Industrial
Declining death rate, high birth rate, rapid growth
Nigeria, Afghanistan


3: Late Industrial
Declining birth rate, slower growth
Mexico, India


4: Post-Industrial
Low birth & death rates, stable growth
USA, Canada


5: Declining
Low birth rate, aging population, negative growth
Japan, Italy



Example: Japan’s Aging Population (Stage 5)

Population shrinking due to low fertility rate (1.3 children per woman).
Impacts: Labor shortages, rising healthcare costs, increased retirement age.
Government response: Encouraging immigration and family-friendly policies.

title: 2  Population and health geography
text:
2.3 Fertility, Mortality, and Migration

2.3.1 Factors Affecting Fertility Rates
High Fertility Rates (Developing Countries)

Limited access to contraception.
Cultural/religious preferences for large families.
Rural economies dependent on children for labor.

Low Fertility Rates (Developed Countries)

Economic cost of raising children.
Increased education and employment for women.
Urbanization reducing family size.



2.3.2 Causes of Mortality (Death Rates)

Infant Mortality Rate (IMR): Deaths of infants <1 year per 1,000 live births.
Life Expectancy: Average lifespan of a population.

Example: Sub-Saharan Africa (High Mortality)

Leading causes: Malaria, HIV/AIDS, malnutrition, lack of healthcare.
Efforts to reduce: Vaccination programs, improved sanitation, healthcare funding.



2.3.3 Migration Patterns

Push Factors (forcing people to leave): War, poverty, natural disasters.
Pull Factors (attracting people): Job opportunities, political stability, better education.

Examples of Large-Scale Migrations:

Syrian Refugee Crisis (2011–present): Millions fleeing war.
Rural-to-urban migration in China: 300 million+ people moving to cities.

title: 2  Population and health geography
text:
2.4 Health Geography

2.4.1 What is Health Geography?
Examines how location affects health and disease spread.
Key topics:

Epidemiology (disease spread).
Healthcare access and inequalities.
Environmental health risks.



2.4.2 Disease Patterns and Epidemics

Endemic: Constantly present in a population (e.g., malaria in Africa).
Epidemic: Sudden outbreak in a region (e.g., Ebola in 2014).
Pandemic: Global outbreak (e.g., COVID-19).

Example: COVID-19 Pandemic (2020–Present)

Origin: Wuhan, China.
Spread: Global air travel, urban density.
Impact: Healthcare strain, lockdowns, economic crisis.

Role of Geography:

GIS mapping for tracking cases.
Urban density affecting transmission.
Global cooperation in vaccine distribution.



2.4.3 Healthcare Access and Inequality

Developed Countries: Universal healthcare, advanced hospitals.
Developing Countries: Poor access, high disease rates.

Example: Healthcare Disparities in the USA

Urban areas have better hospitals vs. rural regions with limited access.
Minority groups have higher infant mortality and lower life expectancy.

title: 2  Population and health geography
text:
2.5 Key takeaways:

Global population is unevenly distributed.
Fertility and mortality rates shape population trends.
Health geography is critical for disease control and healthcare policy.

title: 2  Population and health geography
text:
2.6 Quizzes:

How does population growth impact economic development?
What factors contribute to low fertility rates in some countries?
How has COVID-19 changed global health geography?

授業の目的の説明
This course is designed to provide students with a foundational understanding of human geography and the skills to analyze geographic data using R. Each lesson has specific objectives that contribute to the overall learning goals:
Section 1: Know the foundations of human geography
Section 2: Use the elegant geographic plots in R
Note: All lecture notes, assignments and quizzes will be available through KUTLMS Moodle.

title: 人文地理学
text:
授業の概要

授業の概要の説明
This course provides a comprehensive introduction to human geography, focusing on key themes such as population dynamics, migration, cultural landscapes, and urban development. Additionally, students will learn fundamental techniques for processing and visualizing geographic data using R, applying these skills to real-world geographic analyses across different regions of the world.
Section 1: Know the foundations of human geography
The first section establishes the core principles of human geography, exploring how human societies interact with their environments. Topics include:

The basics of human geography, including spatial patterns and human-environment interactions.
Population trends, migration patterns, and their effects on societies.
Cultural geography, identity formation, and political structures.
The organization of cities and urban spaces, as well as environmental impacts of human activities.

Section 2: Use the elegant geographic plots in R
This section introduces essential geographic data processing techniques, with a focus on:

Handling and analyzing shapefiles using R.
Creating basic maps to visualize geographic data effectively.
Explore human geography case studies from Africa, Asia, Australia, Europe, and North America.
Develop advanced mapping techniques to represent human geographic trends in each region.

title: 人文地理学
text:
到達目標

到達目標の説明
The primary goal of this course is to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of human geography while equipping them with practical skills in geographic data visualization using R. By integrating theoretical knowledge with hands-on data analysis, the course aims to acquire:

Develop a strong foundation in human geography: Students will be able to understand key themes such as population dynamics, migration, cultural landscapes, political geography, and urban development. Understanding these topics will help them analyze how human societies interact with their environments and shape the world.
Enhance analytical and critical thinking skills: Through the study of real-world geographic issues, students will develop the ability to assess spatial patterns, interpret demographic trends, and evaluate the impact of human activities on different regions.
Introduce geographic data processing and visualization: By learning to work with spatial data in R, students will gain essential technical skills, including processing shapefiles, creating maps, and visualizing geographic trends.
Apply knowledge to regional case studies: The course will provide opportunities to apply geographic analysis techniques to different world regions, helping students understand diverse cultural, political, and environmental contexts.

text:
成績評価の方法・基準

成績評価の方法・基準の説明
Attendance, quizzes and assignments account for 50%, and the rest of 50% shall be attributed to the final exam.
AA (Outstanding): Students can effectively operationalize the concepts of human geography, applying them in complex analyses and real-world scenarios.
A (Excellent): Students demonstrate a strong understanding of the concepts of human geography and can draw meaningful implications and interpretations.
B (Good): Students grasp the fundamental concepts of human geography and can apply them to some degree in analysis and interpretation.
C (Fair): Students have a basic understanding of the concepts of human geography and can use them to draw simple conclusions.
F (Failure): Students do not demonstrate an understanding of the fundamental concepts human geography which are necessary for drawing conclusions.
